awd_titl_txt: EAR-PF Salinity Influence on Methane Emissions from Tidal Wetlands Determined by Clumped Isotopes
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2). 

Methane (CH4) is the most abundant organic gas in Earth’s atmosphere, and a greenhouse gas. The EPA estimates indicate that methane accounts for 10% of national greenhouse gas emissions (www.epa.gov/ghgemissions). Methane emissions to the atmosphere include both anthropogenic and natural sources. Of these, wetlands not only play a significant role in the global methane budget, but are also one of the sources with the greatest associated uncertainties. This proposal focuses on wetland methane emissions within the Chesapeake Bay region. This region consists of a variety of environments that produce methane, most notably freshwater tidal wetlands. The proposed research will help characterize the regional methane budget and role of microbial processes that are driven by both natural and anthropogenic forcing of estuarine salinity. This work will support a longer-term project to construct a regional methane cycle model and to model atmospheric methane in this part of the world. Understanding the evolution of the atmospheric methane budget has important implications for local tidal wetlands restoration projects and national climate change policy decisions.

Estimates of methane emissions from tidal wetlands are subject to high uncertainty and commonly suffer from the lack of information, but essential for determining the atmospheric methane budget and its change over time. The proposed research will evaluate the role of salinity (seasonal and regional changes) on microbial methane production and consumption in Maryland wetlands using new methane isotopologue fingerprinting approach. This work will document signatures of carbon and hydrogen in clumped isotopes that depend on varying environmental conditions and seek to develop an isotopologue tracer to track rates of microbial methane production and consumption influenced by environmental factors in different tidal wetlands systems. Using doubly substituted methane isotopologues (clumped isotopes) offers an additional way to resolve uncertainties about the biogenic methane formation pathways under various environmental conditions including the salinity and electron acceptors variability. This study will also address key questions regarding the pathways in methane production and consumption by microbes under the influence of various salinity regimes in tidal wetland systems. The work is a combination of in-situ methane measurements and laboratory (under controlled conditions) experiments. The results of this study will improve our understanding of the role of tidal wetlands in methane budget in Maryland and will be beneficial in environmental policy decisions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Methane is an important green house gas. However, there is a gap in our knowledge about it and the reasons behind the increase of atmospheric methane in the past few decades. From all methane sources wetlands are the most important sources. Methane emission from wetlands is a balance between microbial methane production and consumption. The focus of this project was on a better understanding the effect of seasonal changes on microbial methane production and consumption in tidal wetlands.                                         Methanotrophs reduce methane emission from wetlands; yet, uncertainties persist about grossmicrobial  consumption and the underlying  controlling factors. In oxygen-rich environments, methane is oxidized by bacteria. However, a lack of information about the isotopic signatures of methanotrophy has limited its inclusion in atmospheric isotopic based models. Environmental parameters such as temperature plant distribution and productivity impact methanotrophs. For plant-associated methanotrophy, especially in natural wetlands are not fully understood, and influenced by temperature, seasonal changes, and plant productivity. O2 availability in soil is affected by soil temperature, water table and changes in water depth, and plant distribution androots. Tracking methanotroph seasonal activity in wetlands under different environmental conditionsand plants using traditional monitoring of methane  flux and net methane emissions is challenging as both methanogens and methanotrophs are impacted by these factors, and lower flux can be attributed to low production rate or higher oxidation. This project addresses the effect of plant types and seasonal plant productivity on microbial methane oxidation in an experimental wetland using a novel approach of measuring singly- and doubly-substituted isotopologues. The primary goal was reached through development of field and laboratory analysis to provide insights into methanotrophy in wetlands. The results from this project are able to hlep with: providing insights into methanotroph seasonal activities; identifying which plant communities accelerate methanotroph oxidation; evaluating the conditions that favor methanotrophs over methanogens in wetlands; and determining the potential of plant and vegetation coverage and productivity to shift microbial methane oxidation over seasonal gradients and to decrease methane emission to the atmosphere.                                                                       O2 supply into water and soils, alternative electron acceptors and donors, and temperature are key factors controlling microbial methane (CH4) formation and consumption in wetlands. Correlation of methanotrophy with plants has been determined but not fully understood by studies limited to quantifying CH4 flux and/or under controlled conditions making tracking methanotrophy in response to changes and its efficiency especially in nature a challenge. In this project I investigated seasonal effect of wetland plants and their productivity on microbial CH4 oxidation within the Chesapeake Bay region.                                                 For this purpose, I investigated how methanotroph activity in wetlands changes with seasonal and temperature due to plant productivity in the zones with different types of plant coverage. I developed a new approach that combined clumped isotopologue measurements with field and laboratory experiments to fingerprint microbial CH4 production and oxidation. Clumped isotopes of CH4  provides information about the formation and subsequent processing of CH4 molecules by microbial oxidation. I used clumped isotopes of CH4 to track seasonal microbial production and oxidation in CH4 samples collected directly from different zones of a tidal wetland with diverse plant coverage. The results showed the potential of ∆12CH2D2 in revealing unique information on seasonal CH4 oxidation. Clumped isotope approach in this study not only provided insights into seasonal methanotrophy in wetlands, especially with changes in plant types and other environmental factors butalso produced data sets of unique singly- and doubly-substituted CH4 isotopologues correlated with microbial CH4 oxidation and production. The isotopologue approach circumvents some of the primary issues with concentration- based methods of wetland CH4 fluxes. Clumped isotopes have the potential to show the oxidation signature in CH4 samples and how it changes during the year, providing a way to track and fingerprint seasonal methanotrophy, which is unlikely to be captured with bulk isotope measurements. Information of how microbial CH4 oxidation and production signature changes through the year in the zones with different type of plants. The results also showed which of the plants had a positive impact on methane oxidation rate and which favors microbial methane oxidation over production during the year with changes in seasons and temperature. The result also showed which plants have no effect on methane oxidation. Overall, observed oxidation signature of clumped isotopologues in all locations of sampling changed with temperature and other environmental factors known to impact microbial communities, such as root ventilation, during the growing season. Our results suggest that the new approach using clumped isotopes of methane can provide a method for tracking microbial methane production and consumption. This could allow not only tracking atmospherice methane emission from wetlands but also fingerprinting of microbial wetland contributions to atmospheric air. In addition, I designed some laboratory experiments of soils incubation in different temperatures. The goal of the Laboratory incubation samples of soils from various sites was to investigate microbial communities and their activities.
